Issues.Title: docs(docs-infra): fix marked rendering
Issues.Body:
Follow-up to #57319 which introduced some regressions after updating marked to v14

Fixes #57328, #57335 

Note: I'll look into adding tests to prevent those regressions in the future with a follow-up commit.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs(docs-infra): fix marked rendering" (#57338)

Issues.Title: fix(compiler-cli): reduce false negatives of `interpolatedSignalNotInvoked` extended diagnostic
Issues.Body:
A prior fix in #57291 has introduced the potential for false negatives, as the used directives
that were checked can be present anywhere in the template, not necessarily on the current element
that is being checked. Fixing this requires reshuffling the check's logic a bit, as the extended
diagnostics infrastructure does not provide access to ancestor nodes, nor do the AST nodes
themselves.

The performance regression that was fixed in https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/57291 doesn't reappear with this change, although
it may affect performance slightly as potentially more bindings may end up being checked.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR " fix(compiler-cli): reduce false negatives of `interpolatedSignalNotInvoked` extended diagnostic" (#57337)

Issues.Title: Problem with SSR and condition
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? Don't known / other ### Is this a regression? I don't know ### Description I have the following component template for a sign-in page - if the user is signed in, we show some user info - else we show the login form - we also have some content inside the `@else` block for diagnostic purposes - "user with div" - text inside an html tag - "user without div" - text existing without an html tag - this is a zoneless app - change detection strategy was onPush ```html
@if (user$(); as user) {

Signed in as

{{user.displayName}}

{{user.email}}

} @else {
user (with div)
user (without div) }
``` On the server side, user is always null, because we do not pass authentication headers to the ssr server. Therefore, the html from ssr includes the login form However, it is possible for a user to be detected in the browser (localstorage/cookies/indexeddb/firebase/etc). In that scenario, the user$ signal is populated, and user info is to be shown, while the login form is to be hidden. However, the rendered html looks like this ![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/433443f1-5d75-4af0-b72e-55f3403ba16c) Points to note: - ✔️ the user info was shown - ✔️ the "user without div" part was hidden - ❌ the "user with div part was not hidden - ❌ the login form was not hidden ### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug _No response_ ### Please provide the exception or error you saw _No response_ ### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`) ```true Angular CLI: 18.1.1 Node: 20.16.0 Package Manager: pnpm 9.4.0 OS: linux x64 Angular: 18.1.1 ... animations, cdk, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core ... forms, language-service, material, material-luxon-adapter ... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server ... router, ssr Package Version --------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.1702.2 @angular-devkit/build-angular 18.1.1 @angular-devkit/core 18.1.1 @angular-devkit/schematics 18.1.1 @schematics/angular 18.1.1 ng-packagr 18.1.0 rxjs 7.8.1 typescript 5.5.3 ``` ### Anything else? This is similar to #54201

Issues.Title: Usage Notes page rendering broken on all reference pages
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

On the docs, there is a section on named "Usage Notes" that appears to broken on almost every reference page in the new angular.dev docs. Even ones that are "working" have issues.

For pages that use either `<code-example>` or `{@example}` references are broken entirely and render nothing:
- [AsyncPipe docs](https://angular.dev/api/common/AsyncPipe?tab=usage-notes) ([Source](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/common/src/pipes/async_pipe.ts#L81-L93))
- [TitleCasePipe docs](https://angular.dev/api/common/TitleCasePipe?tab=usage-notes) ([Source](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/common/src/pipes/case_conversion_pipes.ts#L69-L72))

For other pages that use the triple backtick for code blocks, it doesn't remove the backticks in the rendered code blocks:
- [NgIf docs](https://angular.dev/api/common/NgIf?tab=usage-notes) ([Source](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/common/src/directives/ng_if.ts#L67-L152))
- [NgPlural docs](https://angular.dev/api/common/NgPlural?tab=usage-notes) ([Source](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/common/src/directives/ng_plural.ts#L18-L25))

It is especially noticeable on pages that include the language immediately following the backticks:
- [NgOptimizedImage docs](https://angular.dev/api/common/NgOptimizedImage?tab=usage-notes) ([Source](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/common/src/directives/ng_optimized_image/ng_optimized_image.ts#L193-L271))

### Enter the URL of the topic with the problem

All reference pages that contain Usage Notes, see full description

### Describe what you were looking for in the documentation

Was looking for the docs on the TitleCasePipe to determined whether it capitalizes words like "of" and "and" (which is also lacking but deserving of a different story).

### Describe the actions that led you to experience the problem

_No response_

### Describe what you want to experience that would fix the problem

Fix the code renderer on the angular.dev site as it works fine on the old site.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/25e7ebb5-7e26-445b-82d7-d7ac6f3f18eb)

No errors in the console.

Issues.Title: [18.2.x] refactor(migrations): detect if an input is not narrowed and can be migrated
Issues.Body:
By default, we don't migrate inputs if they are part of e.g. `@if` for now. That is because we don't have the template narrowing feature available yet.

To improve impact of the migration until we have the narrowing, we add some additional checks that allow us to migrate instances of inputs that are part of e.g. `@if` but are actually not used inside (and hence are guaranteed to be _not_ narrowed).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[18.2.x] refactor(migrations): detect if an input is not narrowed and can be migrated" (#57323)

Issues.Title: Allow lazy initial value to signal input
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core

### Description

Currently inputs can only accept default values up front. If for some reason the default value is heavier it still gets evaluated even if an input value was bound.

### Proposed solution

Allow passing a function as default value that will only get invoked when there is no bound input (cached later probably).
For example:
```ts
one = input(() => 2);
```

### Alternatives considered

Using a computed this can be achieved right now:
```ts
_one = input<number | undefined>(undefined, {alias: 'one'});
one = computed(() => this._one() ?? 2);
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow lazy initial value to signal input" (#57322)

Issues.Title: refactor(migrations): detect if an input is not narrowed and can be migrated

By default, we don't migrate inputs if they are part of e.g. `@if` for now. That is because we don't have the template narrowing feature available yet.

To improve impact of the migration until we have the narrowing, we add some additional checks that allow us to migrate instances of inputs that are part of e.g. `@if` but are actually not used inside (and hence are guaranteed to be _not_ narrowed).

Issues.Title: Option 'declarationDir' cannot be specified with option 'outFile'.
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

A new library is created in the angular15 project, and the dependency of package.json in the library is set to unpeerdependencies. I hope that this library will be packaged into an index.js that contains all dependencies (when using it, there is no need to introduce dependencies from node_module), in tsconfig When configuring outFile, an error occurs during build: Option 'declarationDir' cannot be specified with option 'outFile'.

### Minimal Reproduction

my tsconfig:
`/* To learn more about this file see: https://angular.io/config/tsconfig. */
{
  "extends": "./tsconfig.lib.json",
  "compilerOptions": {
    "declarationMap": false,
    "outFile": "../../dist/dai-sdk/index.js",
    "module": "AMD",
  },
  "angularCompilerOptions": {
    "compilationMode": "partial"
  }
}
`
tsconfig.lib.json:
/* To learn more about this file see: https://angular.io/config/tsconfig. */
{
  "extends": "../../tsconfig.json",
  "compilerOptions": {
    "declaration": true,
    "declarationMap": true,
    "inlineSources": true,
    "types": []
  },
  "exclude": [
    "**/*.spec.ts"
  ],
  "include": ["**/*"]
}

tsconfig.json:
/* To learn more about this file see: https://angular.io/config/tsconfig. */
{
  "compileOnSave": false,
  "compilerOptions": {
    "baseUrl": "./",
    "sourceMap": true,

Issues.Title: Update component schematic to 'export default class' by default
Issues.Body:
### Command

generate

### Description

The DX has been improved in Angular lazy loading route generation by allowing the removal of the requirement to use `.then(c => c.HomeComponent)` syntax by adding the **default** keyword on the route provider (route file/component/module).

But it comes at the cost of manually opening another file to add this keyword while writing the route definition, making the DX improvment quite limited.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Is there any possible negative impact at making `ng generate component` includes the **default** keyword by default?

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

Issues.Title: --stats-json to allow giving stats to both server and browser, separately
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Description

It would be a lot simpler to debug your stats json if we had a separate server and browser stats. As it is right now, everything is bundled together and is a huge pain trying to figure things out. You have to manually look at what the cli output said was for server and what was for browser, then go through the json and manually separate things. This can take a long time. And then, when you find one thing, you have to build again, just to start the process over to see if you made improvements.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would like a `stats.browser.json` and a `stats.server.json` so I can independently figure out what's being included in the bundle for the server versus the browser.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

There are none that I'm aware of.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "--stats-json to allow giving stats to both server and browser, separately" (#28185)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/ssr): dynamic route resolution using Angular router
Issues.Body:
This enhancement eliminates the dependency on file extensions for server-side rendering (SSR) route handling, leveraging Angular's router configuration for more dynamic and flexible route determination. Additionally, configured redirectTo routes now correctly respond with a 302 redirect status.

The new router uses a radix tree for storing routes. This data structure allows for efficient prefix-based lookups and insertions, which is particularly crucial when dealing with nested and parameterized routes.

This change also lays the groundwork for potential future server-side routing configurations, further enhancing the capabilities of Angular's SSR functionality.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular/ssr): dynamic route resolution using Angular router" (#28183)

Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

I have such stylesheets links (and nothing else more) in `index.html:`
```
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Roboto:wght@300;400;500&display=swap" />
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Material+Symbols+Outlined:opsz,wght,FILL,GRAD@20..48,100..700,0..1,-50..200" />

In `angular.json` as schematics I use:
```
"schematics": {
    "@schematics/angular:component": {

    }
}
```
and `@angular-devkit/build-angular:application` as builder

There is corporate proxy server with address `10.128.0.90:8080` for HTTP and HTTPS. I used to set up proxy configuration in linux and NPM:
```
export HTTP_PROXY=10.128.0.90:8080
export HTTPS_PROXY=10.128.0.90:8080
npm config set proxy http://10.128.0.90:8080
npm config set https-proxy https://10.128.0.90:8080

NPM works well

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/build): lazy load Node.js inspector for dev server
Issues.Body:
The Node.js inspector will now only be imported if SSR is enabled and the `inspect` option is used. This prevents potential failures when a custom Node.js binary build is used that has not enabled inspector usage. While this is not common, loading the inspector on demand is a minimal change that also avoids loading code that will not be used for the majority of development server usage.

Closes #28172
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular/build): lazy load Node.js inspector for dev server" (#28173)

Issues.Title: `ng build` throws on `import inspector from 'node:inspector';` on gentoo default node.js install
Issues.Body:
### Command

build, serve

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

One of our linux enjoyers couldn't build via angular cli due a node.js error: `ERR_INSPECTOR_NOT_AVAILABLE`.

Turns out the `import inspector from 'node:inspector'` from https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/39b00dbb050991f058bc38f45cbda96960c1f6a2/packages/angular/build/src/builders/dev-server/vite-server.ts#L13 fails, as gentoo linux doesn't include the inspector by default. You have to explicitly opt-in via `USE inspector` (https://wiki.gentoo.org/wiki/Node.js / https://packages.gentoo.org/useflags/inspector)

Would be lovely if you could lazyload the `'node:inspector'` package on demand, given that it's a super niche usecase (ssr + inspect enabled)

Feel free to reject if this sounds ridiculous. He already recompiled node.js with injector included by now.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "`ng build` throws on `import inspector from 'node:inspector';` on gentoo default node.js install" (#28172)

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular/build): avoid write file logic for internal application build action
Issues.Body: The internal "buildApplicationInternal" function is only used by several consumers that require writing the output files to disk. One, `browser-esbuild`, directly writes to the disk. The two experimental unit test builders also have unique requirements and also directly write. This leaves only the main `application` builder that relies on the internal file writing functionality of `buildApplicationInternal`. To avoid unneeded logic for the other usages (`dev-server`, `extract-i18n`, unit testing, etc.), the disk writing logic is now elevated to the `application` build itself. The internal function will now always provide the output files within the result objects generated from a successful build. This also removes the need for the other usages to specify that files should not be written to disk.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(@angular/build): avoid write file logic for internal application build action" (#28162)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/build): allow explicitly disabling TypeScript incremental mode
Issues.Body: If the TypeScript `incremental` option is explicitly set to `false`, the `application` builder will no longer attempt to enable and use incremental compilation mode via stored TypeScript build file information. This prevents an potential build time error that would otherwise occur due to the `tsBuildInfoFile` option being set without the `incremental` option. Behavior remains the same if the option is not present or set to `true`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular/build): allow explicitly disabling TypeScript incremental mode" (#28161)

Issues.Title: build: move commit message check to be last in pipeline
Issues.Body:
It occasionally happens that we get a PR that has both the incorrect commit message and a lint failure. The process of fixing it can take multiple runs, because the author has to fix the commit, re-run and then fix the lint failures.

These changes move the commit message check to be last since if everything else passes, the caretaker can fix the commit message while merging the PR.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: move commit message check to be last in pipeline" (#29568)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-select): mat-select dropdown color doesn't support theme switching
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Switching the theme from light mode to dark mode (or vice versa) does not apply the new styles to mat-select's panel.  The mat-select color changes, but the mat-select panel does not.

(I started learning about theming 3 days ago using the angular theming documentation.  It is possible my code is the issue)

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-ex6hok?file=src%2Fglobal_styles.scss
Steps to reproduce:
1. Click the dropdown (memorize the panel background color)
2. Select "Light Theme"
3. Notice the Select changed colors, but the dropdown panel did not.

To view the correct colors
1. Go to global_styles.scss
2. Modify line 10 to `@include mat.all-component-themes(theme.$light-theme);`
3. Ignore the color of the mat-select being wrong, only look at the panel.


### Expected Behavior

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8e5a9745-7487-48b2-9e4b-ce270f628020)


### Actual Behavior

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/72fc83d9-fa9b-4d61-8a72-7a20c6e3adbc)


### Environment

- Angular: 18.1.4
- CDK/Material:  18.1.4
- Browser(s): Chrome, Firefox
- Operating System: Ubuntu

Issues.Title: bug(mat-form-field): mat-error renders incorrectly if not a direct child of mat-form-field
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

`mat-error` renders incorrectly, if it is not a direct child node of a `mat-form-field`.

In other words: Wrapping `mat-error` into an `ng-container` is enough to break its rendering. This is unexpected, since `ng-container`s should have no impact on rendering. This confuses developers and makes the code error-prone.

Some practical examples: cl/633574654, cl/660607399

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/hixrmb?file=src%2Fexample%2Fform-field-error-example.html
(forked from https://material.angular.io/components/form-field/examples#form-field-error)

Steps to reproduce: 
1. Open the demo
2. Observe that the input is too high
3. Put focus on the input. Then blur.
4. Observe that the error renders within the input.


### Expected Behavior

`ng-container` should have no impact on the rendering of the error message.

### Actual Behavior

Wrapping the `mat-error` into an `ng-container` makes it render incorrectly.

### Environment

- Angular: 18.0.1
- CDK/Material: 18.1.4
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Linux
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(mat-form-field): mat-error renders incorrectly if not a direct child of mat-form-field" (#29558)

Issues.Title: fix(material/tabs): allow for tablist aria-label and aria-labelledby to be set
Issues.Body:
According to the [W3C reference implementation](https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/tabs/), the inner `tablist` can be labelled using `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby`. These changes add an input to allow them to be set.

Fixes #29486.

Issues.Title: bug(material/select): Material 3 mat-selects use the secondary color for selected item backgrounds (when the component is styled to primary)
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The styling of a select (mat-select) highlights the background of a selected element. However even when you are using the default 'primary' styling of a select (as documented https://material.angular.io/guide/theming#using-component-color-variants) the background highlighting of the selected option in the select uses the secondary palette.

![Screenshot 2024-08-07 at 10 23 41 AM](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/435d9bfb-1856-41f3-a5a6-7839c92d1439)



### Reproduction

This is a stackblitz forked from the `mat-select` documentation. It has been adjusted to use custom styles as produced by the output of `ng generate @angular/material:m3-theme` with the following colors: primary: `ff0000`, secondary: `00ff00`, tertiary: `0000ff`. The generated m3-theme.scss was copied over into that stack blitz and `m3-theme.$light-theme` was then used for `@include mat.all-component-themes(m3-theme.$light-theme)` in `styles.scss`

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/nngoxu-ggvcsg?file=src%2Fstyles.scss
Steps to reproduce:
1. click to select element to open up the options list; note the background of the selected element is miscolored


### Expected Behavior

I would expect that the selected background color of a given palette to either be static (as in M2's `rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.04)`) or to be based on the colors in the palette chosen to style that component.

Possible work arounds:
* Use material provided palettes (ie mat.$red-palette). 
* Use a secondary color / palette that is produced as a variant the primary color / palette.
* Set the css variable `--mat-option-selected-state-layer-color`. 

For my code I went with option 3; `--mat-option-selected-state-layer-color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.04);`. Note for option 3, as this is styling something in a `cdk-overlay-container` you have to make sure that your override still applies. 

### Actual Behavior

The background color of a 'primary' (default) styled select appears to be using the color as specified in the secondary palette at the '90' level. This 'works' when you use the included scss material palettes because the 'secondary' palette is bundled as a subelement of that palette. A trimmed version of the 'rose' palette (rose/red is one of the styling options on the angular material page), as found in @angular/material/core/themeing/_palettes.scss looks like 

```
/// Rose color palette to be used as primary or tertiary palette.
$rose-palette: _apply-patches((
  0: #000000,
  10: #3f001b,
  <... color levels ...>
  secondary: (
    <... color levels ...>
    90: #ffd9e1, // this is what the selected element actually uses on material.angular.io when using the 'Rose and Red' theme
    <... more color levels>
  ),
  neutral: (
    <... color levels...>
  ),
  neutral-variant: (
     <... color levels ...>
  ),
));
```
So even for the documentation stylings all of the secondary palettes are mutated forms of the primary palettes and so the selected element's background looks good. When using the `ng generate @angular/material:m3-theme` no such binding between the primary palette & secondary palette is implied or generated. So when it selects a secondary.90 for styling the background of a primary styled mat-select component it looks wrong.


### Environment

- Angular: 18.0.1
- CDK/Material: 18.1.3
- Browser(s): chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOs
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(material/select): Material 3 mat-selects use the secondary color for selected item backgrounds (when the component is styled to primary)" (#29553)

Issues.Title: feat(datepicker): Support fixed height with displaying trailing and leading days of surrounding months
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

Currently the Angular Material implementation of the Material date picker only seems to display the current month's days, without the trailing days of the previous month and leading days of the next month (if any).
An example of the current UI:
![angularmaterialdatepicker](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/77815f09-45fb-44ee-963f-9eb0dee5ec50)

However when switching between months, the height of the component changes depending on the alignment of the weeks within the currently viewed month.

![angmatdate](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c68d5ac4-faea-4224-ac5a-c14ce156cb44)


This request is for the Angular Material date picker to support displaying the trailing/leading days and maintain a fixed height, which particularly when inline, is much easier to design for when developing a surrounding layout compared to a component that has variable/jumping height.

The Date picker in the Material 3 spec does seem to support this as shown:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/eb71e4f6-ea3f-4f60-8b27-7999bb0cc3f9)
(From https://m3.material.io/components/date-pickers/specs)



### Use Case

_No response_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(datepicker): Support fixed height with displaying trailing and leading days of surrounding months" (#29549)

Issues.Title: bug(button-toggle): Mixin does not support color variants
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

According to [documentation](https://material.angular.io/guide/theming#using-component-color-variants), the MatButtonToggle component can be stylized using 4 color variants: 

> | Component | Supported $color-variant values | Default |
> |--------|--------|--------|
> | Button-toggle | primary, secondary, tertiary, error | secondary |

But when I use the mixin `@include mat.button-toggle-color(theme.$light-theme, $color-variant: primary);` I get the following error:
```
"Invalid color variant: primary. Mixin does not support color variants."
    ╷
123 │       token-utils.get-tokens-for($tokens, tokens-mat-standard-button-toggle.$prefix, $options...);
    │       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    ╵
  node_modules\@angular\material\button-toggle\_button-toggle-theme.scss 123:7  -theme-from-tokens()
  node_modules\@angular\material\button-toggle\_button-toggle-theme.scss 38:5   color()
  src\styles.scss 36:2                                                          root stylesheet
```



### Reproduction

Setup a regular Material 3 project and copy/paste:
```
@use '@angular/material' as mat;

:root {
   @include mat.button-toggle-theme($theme);
   @include mat.button-toggle-color($theme, $color-variant: primary);
}

```
Replace `$theme` with a M3 theme.

### Expected Behavior

All styles for color variant should be included.

### Actual Behavior

Error is thrown.

### Environment

- Angular: 18.1.3
- CDK/Material: 18.1.3
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(button-toggle): Mixin does not support color variants" (#29547)

Issues.Title: bug(typography): Huge typography differences between material 2 and material 3
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

M2

### Description

Including the typography using the typography-hierarchy mixin ```@include mat.typography-hierarchy($theme)``` adds some default styling for some html dom elements. 

For the headings elements h1..h6 there seems to be a huge difference in font-sizes. To compare H1 was set to 20px while now it is set to 44px. I find that to be a huge difference and really not matching the rest of the font-sizes.

In the code I see that for headings, the display typescales are used. Is it the correct one? Seems to me that those are not very web friendly scales.

### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/stackblitz-starters-6yln2x?file=src%2Fstyles.scss

### Expected Behavior

Adequate font sizes for heading elements

### Actual Behavior

Huge headings which are incompatible with the rest of the application

### Environment

@angular-devkit/architect    0.1801.2

But when I'm at the end of the scrolled div (right), I scroll left and click on a MatSelect to change directory, the container jump to the end and do not let me select option...
